repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Erzincan Earthquake Rehabilitation
            and Reconstruction Project, Turkey Emergency Flood and
            Earthquake Recovery Project, and Emergency Earthquake
            Recovery Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings for the Erzincan
            Earthquake Rehabilitation and Reconstruction Project, Turkey
            Emergency Flood and Earthquake Recovery Project, and
            Emergency Earthquake Recovery Project are as follows: For
            all three projects, project outcomes are rated satisfactory;
            sustainability is likely; Bank performance is satisfactory;
            and Borrower performance is satisfactory. The institutional
            development impact for the Emergency Earthquake Recovery
            Project is substantial, while the other two projects
            received ratings of modest for this aspect. Lessons for
            disaster recovery suggested by the experience of these
            projects included: 1) The support the Bank promptly provided
            enabled people to survive, put funds into the economy, and
            was reported as highly preferable to in-kind support by
            beneficiaries. 2)  Greater accuracy of damage assessments is
            still needed to avoid unnecessary construction. 3)
            Addressing the social and economic recovery aspects of
            emergency projects, although difficult, is critical for the
            sustainability of the reconstruction investments. 4)
            Creating New Disaster Management Institutions takes more
            time than is available under one project. 5) Cash Transfer
            projects can make an extremely important contribution to
            recovery. Getting cash support to victims quickly positively
            affected the economy and perhaps even affected people's
            sense of safety and security. It was a prominent first sign
            of the government's support in a time of acute need.

repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Earthquake Rehabilitation and
            Reconstruction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Earthquake Rehabilitation and
            Reconstruction Project's outcome and achievement of
            project objectives is rated as satisfactory. However, there
            were several problems during the first three years of the
            project with the selection and work of the consultants who
            assisted Housing Development Administration with design and
            construction supervision for the four main construction
            components. These difficulties significantly contributed to
            the initial implementation delays. Furthermore, there was
            poor government commitment to the institutional components
            attempting to strengthen Turkey's preparedness for
            future earthquakes. The lessons learned from this project
            include: 1) Give preventive and institutional development
            measures a more prominent role. 2) Maintain reasonable
            Quality at Entry even for urgent projects. 3) Local
            involvement is key to success. 4) Seek to limit the number
            of sectors included. 5) Avoid extensions. It would have been
            better to close the project in 1996 and identify new
            operations in response to future disasters on the basis of
            the merits of those cases.

5082214.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Rural development,Urban development,Social protection and risk management

repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Earthquake Rehabilitation and
            Reconstruction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the multisectoral
            project is to reconstruct essential housing, infrastructure
            and other facilities to promptly restore economic activity
            in the affected area.  The project will finance demolition,
            reconstruction, rehabilitation, and repair activities in the
            urban and rural areas including: (a) cooperative and
            government housing, hospitals, office and shop buildings and
            key infrastructure; (b) procurement of critical commodities
            including livestock, and (c) training and studies to reduce
            earthquake vulnerability.  Bank involvment will help prevent
            the recurrence of similar earthquake damage in the future by
            providing technical training for the construction industry,
            identifying existing public buildings which can be
            structurally reinforced through retrofitting, and upgrading
            the institutional and financial arrangements which deal with
            disasters in Turkey.

Turkey - Earthquake Rehabilitation and
